The drive along the coast was a beautiful precursor to this beach. There is limited parking and it was busy so we had to wait briefly. The drive to the beach is long, narrow and quite bumpy. We were glad we were in a truck. It wasn't pleasant meeting cars and trying to squeeze by each other. Once parked it is a short walk to the beach. It opens up into paradise! The beach is clean with breathtaking views! We were in awe of the pink and purple sand. Several brave people were climbing the huge rough rock formations and I'm sure they got quite a view. The ocean provides beauty with rolling waves washing through big crevices in the rock. There were little sea urchins to watch on the rock further down on the beach. Sea lions popped up and down. Very relaxing and quite a sight at sunset. We're glad we ventured this far to see such beauty!

Place is great, but let's talk about the road.

Great beach and picturesque location. At the beach, i made the mistake thinking that the first rock was the main one with the opening, but it is the second one that is it. Everything is great about the beach as others have reviewed. There are 2 parking lots, a closer one that is a loop and an upper lot. I just parked in the upper and walked to avoid the people waiting for spots at the lower lot.

Let's talk about the one lane road that leads to the beach. It is narrow. There are blind turns. It is bumpy at times. Please have courtesy and do not tail gate. I had another car tail gate me from the start up at highway 1. I went as fast as I cautiously could with the bumps and curves, but he was on my tail the whole time. About half way down, I pulled to the side to let another van pass coming up. He tried to get around me, but then saw the van and slammed on his brakes and had to reverse back up. I think that gave him a hint. He was better the rest of the way. I went into the upper lot and he sped past to the lower lot. When we were leaving he was somehow behind me again, but this time he wised up. He kept a safe distance and just let me go at it at my pace.

It is easier to see ahead on the way out of the beach than on the way to it, in my opinion. Please turn your lights on. It really helps as I would look through the trees up ahead to see if there were any lights coming.

All in all, you gotta check the place out. Just drive slow on the road and let a tailgaters pass.

Also be prepared for your feet to get wet. We tried the our best, but some of those sneaker waves just get you.

We drove along the PCH from Hearst Castle to Monterey and Pfeiffer Beach was a must stop on my list. Not only that, but from my research, we HAD to see it at sunset, and wow, it did not disappoint. Be sure to check the sunset time (weather apps) when you'll be there and plan accordingly. Google maps worked for us to find the right spot. The road down to it was a bit rough--slow down along the 1 as you come up to it, because it's easily missable. It's 1.5 lanes wide, so be prepared to pull over to let people pass, there are no lines or reflectors and no lights, which makes navigating it at night a bit more difficult than usual. Just when you think you might turn around, because really, it seems pretty creepy, you reach the main parking lot. The lot isn't large, but a couple of people were leaving when we got there. We were there just before Thanksgiving, so with the wind, it was chilly--bring a fleece and windbreaker! But that also meant people typically didn't seem to stay more than 20-30 minutes (so pull over and wait for a parking spot). You walk a couple of blocks-worth across mostly flat sand, and if you go at sunset, you'll see the jaw dropping beauty of the sun about to come through the main arch. Be patient with all the people trying to get the same pictures from the same spot--the sun moves slowly, so you'll get your chance. The drone was a bit annoying though--ruined a few pictures. Experiencing sunset here at Pfeiffer Beach was the highlight of our trip.

Located at the end of a 1.5 to 2 mile trek on a 1 lane winding dirt stone road from Hwy 1. If you start off for your hike to the beach at one of the parking lots or even if you are dropped off, on the path that takes you to the beach you are going to be navigating in sand and pebbles. (This is not a Southern Cali beach, with beautiful sands that you would want to throw down a beach towel to catch a few rays on). This is one the "Wild Children" of Cali beaches. Once you hit the beach area you become one with nature and her elements. It gets somewhat windy, and misty and there is lots and lots of Kelp that has washed up onto the beach to navigate around. Everytime that I've been here it's been chilly and the sky is gray, but I've enjoyed watching the rolling waters of the Pacific crash in along all the rocky outcrops that make up this beach along with a seagull buddy of mine we spent a good portion of the time watching people scaling to the top of one of the outcrops, "Just because it's there" or so I was told by one of my friends who did the climb.

We were there while the majority of if not almost all of the parks and beaches in Sur were closed (baracaded was/is a more apt description) but very understandable due to the Soberanes Wild Fire that was still burning around us. To find Pfeiffer Beach open at that time was nothing short of amazing.

I'm sure that if I find myself back in the Big Sur area, which I hope that I do, I'll look forward to a revisit.

We passed the turning without noticing it the first time, as there is no obvious indication that you need to turn off the highway, so it's worth googling it and making a note of the mileage from wherever you're travelling.

Wear good shoes. All the best views involve a little bit of scrambling on wet, slippery rock!

Pacific Ocean tides break through huge rocks with holes. Dolphins, whales and seals play out a ways. A stroll north on the beach eludes the crowds and allows for a peaceful reside. The granite sand does not stick to your feet and is colorful too. This is one of my favorite beaches in the world. Not to be missed when on Highway 1.

Great beach with impressive view. We have been there at the dawn but it was beautiful anyway. Don't know if it is good for sunbathing or swimming but take a moment and go there if you are driving through Big Sur. It is forth it.

Simply an amazing must stop when adventuring in Big Sur. It can be found by making a sharp right turn shortly after Big Sur Station at a yellow Narrow Road sign. Then you will follow a LONG, NARROW, WINDING road to the beach where you will pay $10 for access. There are 2 parking lots then it is a short walk to the amazing beach.

You will see the Sun Portal quickly. And there are amazing rock formations right beside it. You'll be mesmerized by the ocean waves crashing onto the shore.

You will also find purple sand on this beach but for the deepest purple you should definitely walk along the beach to the area where there will also be less people.

Not a beach to sun yourself. DRAMATIC views of crashing waves against rock formations and a purple cast to the sand. An adventure to find and drive down to the parking lot.

Pfeiffer is a narrow strip of beach, its windy and the water is rough, so don't imagine anything else, but its one way to get close to the water, and it gives you some memorable photos. The parking at $10 is expensive and if i remember they only take cash and that, too, they prefer exact change! The road down from the main road is narrow and takes about 15 minutes to negotiate the 2 mile stretch. Round trip with the visit to the beach strip could well take an hour and thats if you're fairly quick.

This is a Hidden Beach and very hard to find,we were told to look for the yellow sign "Narrow Road", which you can see if you're driving south of Pfeiffer Big Sur State Park,The turnoff to get to the beach is about a mile. Then a two mile drive on a one lane 2 way narrow windy road leads to the entrance to Pfeiffer Beach,you may have to pull over( turnouts )to let someone pas .you have to pay a $10 admission fee which is well worth it. Luckily we found a Parking space in the parking lots as it is limited. It's a bit of a walk to the beach from the Parking Area
The beach is Absolutely beautiful with the small river and the patches of Purple Sand,it was fun walking on the beach and enjoying the natural beauty of the rock formations and coves with waves crashing through .

Very difficult to get to, $10.00 for parking, and it gets packed with people. Go early! Totally worth the hassle though.

It's a 2 mile drive down a narrow, winding road to a gatehouse that takes $10 to let you park. There's a sign that says high winds, but there's enough people going I just though it meant blustery. The man working the gate said nothing.

It's HIGH DRIVING WINDS that beat sand into every pore of your body and the fabric of your clothing. It's HIGH WINDS that push you down the beach. It's unpleasant at best. Wild and beautiful terrain that could be wonderful to enjoy on a calm day.

If you do go there, be sure there are NO WHITE CAPS on the ocean. That is perfectly still. Then go. Take pictures in the gorgeous archway and marvel at the streaks of purple sand.

It has soft purple sand, amazing rock and cave formations that you experience very close by and extraordinary views!

We tried for hours to get to the beach and kept getting turned away at the top of the road because the parking lot was full. Finally at around 5pm when the guy saw us return for the 4th or 5th time he let us pass to the parking lot. From the top of the road it is about a 3 mile drive to the parking lot on a 2 way 1 lane road. Curves in the road made the trip very exciting, never knowing if there would be a car head on around the corner. Right before the parking lot entrance was a flooded dip in the road, that I'm sure would have been a challenge if we were in a smaller car. Parking was $10/cash only. Bathrooms located by the parking lot. Short sand path to the beach. Beach is beautiful with rock formations, huge waves and purple sand. So glad we were persistent and kept trying back for open parking, had never seen a beach quite like this before. Waves so strong when we were there you could hear the rocks tumbling in the surf. Well worth the effort to get to!

Off the beaten path with built in crowd control. They only let in a limited number of vehicles, so be prepared for a potential wait. It is so worth it and likely had a spectacular sunset. I wish we could have spent more time here!

My girlfriend and I made the hour trip south from Monterey to explore Big Sur. Pfeiffer Beach was our first stop as I had read that it gets packed early. We arrived around 10:30 and there were a max of 10 cars in the parking lot. I don't know how "early" Californians get going, but we left the beach around 11:30 and there were still lots of spots in the lot.

The beach itself is awesome- lots to explore. The purple sand is a unique feature. Personally, I enjoyed being able to explore and climb on the rocks to get photo opportunities.

I would highly recommend this stop and if you get there "early"- ie. before 11 (that's not really early) you'll have plenty of parking and space to roam the geologic beauty which is Pfeiffer Beach

We arrived at Pfeiffer Beach first thing in the morning and were told the lot was already full. We reluctantly turned around and parked across the street ready to hoof it the 2 miles in. Well, it is not an easy hike. Down would be easier than out but the road is narrow and not in great condition. We hitchhiked and caught a ride both ways. To our surprise when we arrived the lot was not even close to full. The short walk to the beach is very wooded and pretty but this beach - one of the most beautiful. The purple sands and rock formations. I give it a 10. I would spend a whole day here if the sun was out, unfortunately it was cloudy when we were there. Note - this is a dog-friendly beach and there will be lots of dogs here. I didn't note any waste though, so thank you for picking up after them!

It's true! There is purple sand!

I was very skeptical about seeing purple sand, but we saw it. Now, the entire beach is not purple, but there truly is some purple sand. The turnoff to get to the beach is very hard to see but I took a quick picture of the entrance right after we turned off the highway to show you. The name of the road is Sycamore Canyon Road. Also, it's a very narrow 2 miles to get to the parking lot and you are wondering at times where in the world you are going! But that made for the adventure of getting there and a more exciting trip. Parking is limited but we were able to find a spot. The restrooms have no running water but are clean, A quick hike on a well marked trail and we were there. I'm glad we took the time to find this gem. Note: I believe your pass to this park gets you in to other state parks so keep that in mind if you are planning to stop at other spots along the coast!
